text: Inhibition of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 replication by a <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activated , transduced interferon gene : targeted expression to human immunodeficiency virus type 1-infected cells .
We have examined the feasibility of using interferon ( IFN ) gene transfer as a novel approach to anti-human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) therapy in this study .

To limit expression of a transduced HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) - IFNA2 ( the new approved nomenclature for IFN genes is used throughout this article ) hybrid gene to the HIV-1-infected cells , HIV-1 LTR was modified .

Deletion of the NF-kappa B elements of the HIV-1 LTR significantly inhibited <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated transactivation in T-cell lines , as well as in a monocyte line , U937 .

Replacement of the NF-kappa B elements in the HIV-1 LTR by a DNA fragment derived from the 5'-flanking region of IFN - stimulated gene 15 ( ISG15 ) , containing the IFN - stimulated response element , partially restored <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated activation of LTR in T cells as well as in monocytes .

Insertion of this chimeric promoter ( ISG15 LTR ) upstream of the human <extra_id_0> IFNA2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene directed high levels of IFN synthesis in <extra_id_0> Tat <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - expressing cells , while this promoter was not responsive to <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated activation .
ISG15-LTR-IFN hybrid gene inserted into the retrovirus vector was transduced into Jurkat and U937 cells .

Selected transfected clones produced low levels of <extra_id_0> IFN A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IFNA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) constitutively , and their abilities to express <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and interleukin-2 receptor upon stimulation with <extra_id_0> phytohemagglutinin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and phorbol myristate acetate were retained .

text: Enhancement of <extra_id_0> IFNA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis observed upon HIV-1 infection resulted in significant inhibition of HIV-1 replication for a period of at least 30 days .

text: Virus isolated from <extra_id_0> IFNA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - producing cells was able to replicate in the U937 cells but did not replicate efficiently in U937 cells transduced with the <extra_id_0> IFNA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

These results suggest that targeting IFN synthesis to HIV-1-infected cells is an attainable goal and that autocrine IFN synthesis results in a long-lasting and permanent suppression of HIV-1 replication .
